user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_read_map_attr:
```c
static int metal_uio_read_map_attr(struct linux_device *ldev,
				   unsigned int index,
				   const char *name,
				   unsigned long *value)
{
	const char *cls = ldev->cls_path;
	struct sysfs_attribute *attr;
	char path[SYSFS_PATH_MAX];
	int result;

	result = snprintf(path, sizeof(path), "%s/maps/map%u/%s", cls, index, name);
	if (result >= (int)sizeof(path))
		return -EOVERFLOW;
	attr = sysfs_open_attribute(path);
	if (!attr || sysfs_read_attribute(attr) != 0) {
		sysfs_close_attribute(attr);
		return -errno;
	}

	*value = strtoul(attr->value, NULL, 0);

	sysfs_close_attribute(attr);
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No calls to any of the <string.h> functions listed in MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn) appear in this function. The string operations present are snprintf (from <stdio.h>) and strtoul (from <stdlib.h>), which are outside the scope of Rule 21.17. The snprintf use includes a truncation check (result >= sizeof(path)) so the local buffer construction does not present an obvious <string.h> bounds violation. The only other string data access is attr->value passed to strtoul; strtoul is not a <string.h> function. Note: implementations of sysfs_open_attribute/sysfs_read_attribute/sysfs_close_attribute (and the type/contents of attr->value) are outside this function — if those functions use <string.h> APIs internally, they should be inspected separately, but that is beyond the provided code fragment. Therefore no code fragments in the provided function need investigation under Rule 21.17.
